description: Louis Sarkozy, the son of former president Nicolas Sarkozy, will run for mayor in Menton, where several investigations are open into the local administration.

headline: China outraged by Mexico's automotive tariffs
description: The Mexican government announced plans to raise import taxes to 50% on 1,400 products – including automobiles – imported primarily from China, India, and South Korea. Beijing, viewing this as a pro-American maneuver, threatened retaliation.

headline: 2025 Emmy Awards: Seth Rogen and Jean Smart are among the early winners at 2025 Emmy Awards
description: Stephen Colbert was the first person to take the stage to present the award during the CBS telecast at the Peacock Theater in Los Angeles, despite the recent controversial cancellation of his show by the network. He was greeted by a rousing and lengthy standing ovation.

headline: The thorny issue of splitting expenses in a relationship: 'Going 50/50 is a scam'
description: When moving in together, the question of 'who pays for what?' is often avoided. To break this taboo, social media content encourages couples to manage their finances more fairly, particularly to ensure that women are less disadvantaged.

description: Tyler Robinson, arrested on Thursday night, is a 22-year-old White man who grew up in a conservative family in Utah and was a brilliant high school student. Nothing in his background supports the theory being propagated in MAGA circles that he is a far-left activist.

headline: Israeli intelligence admits Iran's nuclear program has not been destroyed
description: Israeli officials have recently provided French authorities with their own assessment of the airstrikes that targeted Tehran's nuclear arsenal in June. This information is particularly valuable to France after American intelligence agencies have halted all cooperation with their European partners regarding the Iranian nuclear program.

headline: Why French politics can't cope without an absolute majority
description: While most European countries have learned to manage their fragmented parliaments, France has failed to adapt. The 'fait majoritaire,' the political dominance of a president backed by a parliamentary majority, has so deeply shaped politics since 1962 that lawmakers have been unable to envision governments built on a base of negotiation and compromise.
